LOAN AND PROGRAM SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Republic of Indonesia  
   
The Proposal  The  Infrastructure  Reform  Sector  Development  Program  (IRSDP) 
consists  of  a  cluster  of  three  back-to-back  subprograms,  a  project 
development  facility  (PDF)  for  the  preparation  and  transaction 
execution of public–private partnership (PPP) infrastructure projects, 
and technical assistance (TA) for enhancing private sector participation 
(PSP)  in  infrastructure  provision.  In  November  2006,  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  approved  a  loan  of  $400  million  for 
subprogram 1, a loan of $26.5 million equivalent for the PDF, a grant of 
$2.0 million for the TA, and administration by ADB of a $7.6 million 
grant provided by the Government of the Netherlands for the PDF. The 
current proposal comprises a loan of $280 million for subprogram 2 of 
the IRSDP. 
   
Classification  Targeting classification: General intervention 
Sector: Multisector 
Themes:  Sustainable  economic  growth,  private  sector  development, 
governance 
Subthemes:  Fostering  physical  infrastructure  development,  public–
private  partnerships,  promoting  economic  efficiency  and  enabling 
markets 
   
Environment  Category C  
Assessment 
   
Program Rationale  Combined public and private sector investments in the infrastructure 
sectors in Indonesia exceeded 5% of gross domestic product (GDP) in 
the mid-1990s. The Asian financial crisis of 1997 led to a steep decline 
in  overall  development  spending,  and  particularly  infrastructure 
investments.  Private  sector  investment  almost  disappeared.  At  the 
same time, the Government realized that the public sector had borne a 
disproportionate  share  of  the  risks  in  infrastructure  projects,  and 
stopped providing any risk-sharing support. As a result, Indonesia has 
lost its place as one of the top performers in terms of infrastructure 
provision  in  the  Southeast  Asian  region.  Poor  people  suffer 
disproportionately from lack of access to basic infrastructure services. 
Availability  of  services  is  generally  lower  in  rural  areas,  particularly 
outside Java and Bali, contributing to significant regional disparities in 
development. 
 
At  the  outset  of  its  term,  the  Government  estimated  that  about 
$65 billion would be needed in new infrastructure investments during 
2005–2009, with $25 billion (38%) to be sourced from its budget, $14 
billion (22%) from domestic banks and insurance and pension funds, 
$10 billion (15%) from multilateral and bilateral development partners, 
and  $16  billion  (25%)  from  domestic  and  foreign  private  sector 
investors.  Given  the  weak  investment  climate,  the  Government 
recognized that PSP could not be taken for granted, and that major 
structural  and  institutional  reforms  were  needed.  The  IRSDP,

ii    
formulated  jointly  by  the  Government  and  its  principal  development 
partners, supports a comprehensive medium-term reform agenda in 
eight infrastructure sectors.        
 
The program loan support three key reform pillars: 
 
(i)  strategic cross-sector reforms; 
(ii)  sector-specific reforms for transportation, power, oil and gas, 
water supply and sanitation, and telecommunications; and 
(iii)  facilitation of the preparation and execution of well-structured 
PPP  transactions,  resulting  in  sound  model  infrastructure 
projects that can be replicated. 
   
Impact and  The IRSDP, of which subprogram 2 is an integral part, aims to improve 
Outcome  Indonesia’s  overall  investment  climate  by  removing  infrastructure 
bottlenecks  and  increasing  access  to  infrastructure  services,  and 
thereby support timely realization of the Government’s medium-term 
macroeconomic goals, in particular average GDP growth of 6%–7% per 
annum  during  2005–2009.  The  expected  outcome  of  the  IRSDP  is 
accelerated  infrastructure  development  through  major  PSP  and 
mobilization of additional public sector resources. 
 
The  initial  impact  of  the  IRSDP  has  been  positive.  GDP  growth 
accelerated  from  5.0%  in  2004  to  6.3%  in  2007,  and  annual 
infrastructure investments rose from 2.9% of GDP in 2005 to 3.3% in 
2006. 
   
Program Investment  For  subprogram  1,  in  November  2006  ADB  provided  a  loan  of 
Plan  $400  million.  This  was  followed  in  March  2007  by  cofinancing  of 
  $100  million  from  the  Government  of  Japan.  Similar  cofinancing  is 
planned by the Government of Japan for the $280 million ADB loan 
proposed  for  subprogram  2  in  2008.  The  World  Bank  has  been 
supporting the reform agenda through its Infrastructure Development 
Policy Loan program. The first loan of $200 million was approved in 
December 2007, and the same amount is considered for the second 
loan  in  2008.  The  loans  of  the  three  development  partners  for 
subprogram 3 are expected to be in the same order of magnitude and 
will  be  reconfirmed  during  further  implementation  of  the  IRSDP  in 
2009–2010.  
   
Financing Plan  The $280 million for subprogram 2 will be provided from ADB’s ordinary 
capital resources under ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-
based lending facility. The loan will have a 15-year term, including a 
grace period of 3 years, an interest rate determined in accordance with 
ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility, a commitment charge of 0.15% per 
annum,  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  set  forth  in  the  draft 
program loan agreement.

iii 
Period and  Subprogram 1 was completed between January 2005 and September 
Tranching  2006. Subprogram 2 timing is from October 2006 up to September 
2008,  and  the  period  for  subprogram  3  is  from  October  2008  to 
September  2010.  All  three  program  loans  are  disbursed  in  single 
tranches upon declaration of their effectiveness. 
   
Executing Agency  The National Development Planning Agency (BAPPENAS), under the 
overall coordination of the National Committee on the Acceleration of 
Infrastructure Provision (KKPPI) has been the Executing Agency for the 
IRSDP.  BAPPENAS  has  closely  collaborated  with  the  Coordinating 
Ministry of Economic Affairs, Ministry of Finance, and the line ministries 
concerned  with  executing  the  IRSDP  and  implementing  the  reform 
actions.  
   
Procurement  The loan proceeds will be used to finance the full foreign exchange 
costs (excluding local duties and taxes) of items produced and procured 
in  ADB  member  countries,  excluding  ineligible  items  and  imports 
financed by other bilateral and multilateral sources. The loan proceeds 
will be disbursed to the Borrower in accordance with the provisions of 
ADB’s  Simplification  of  Disbursement  Procedures  and  Related 
Requirements for Program Loans.  
   
Program Benefits  The IRSDP’s expected benefits include 
and Beneficiaries  (i)  sustained progress in meeting the Government’s macroeconomic 
objectives articulated in its Medium-Term Development Plan for 
2004–2009; 
(ii)  an improved investment climate resulting from sound policy, legal, 
and institutional frameworks in the infrastructure sectors; 
(iii)  greater PSP and a more systematic approach to implementing 
PPP transactions, focusing on good governance; 
(iv)  a transparent and prudent risk-sharing system; 
(v)  quality infrastructure projects prepared and executed transparently 
and expeditiously, resulting in (a) improved availability and quality 
of  infrastructure  services,  (b)  a  boost  to  Indonesia’s 
competitiveness in regard to its regional neighbors, and (c) a lower 
incidence of poverty; 
(vi)  sustained engagement by ADB in policy reforms over the medium 
term to strengthen the investment climate; and 
(vii)  aid harmonization by the principal development partners (ADB, the 
World Bank, and the Government of Japan) around a common 
policy framework, and the positive externalities resulting from joint 
endorsement of the Government’s reform agenda. 
   
Risks and  Government Commitment. The political commitment could possibly 
Assumptions  waver  because  of  internal  disagreements  over  policy  directions,  or 
because the entire Government may change after the elections in 2009. 
The majority of opinions within the current Government confirm the 
notion that the Government remains strongly committed to the reform 
program embodied in the IRSDP and the complementing Infrastructure 
Development Policy Loan program. The 2009 elections pose only a 
moderate  risk  of  weakened  commitment  and  a  loss  of  the  reform 
momentum, as even with a change of Government, the new leaders are 
expected  to  continue  focusing  on  economic  growth  and  poverty

iv    
reduction to ensure a sound tenure in office and mitigate social and 
political  unrest.  However,  should  the  new  Government  not  be 
committed to maintaining reform momentum, subprogram 3 could be 
delayed or cancelled.  
 
Government  Coordination.  At  times,  the  progress  of  infrastructure 
reforms has been impeded by poor coordination among government 
ministries  and  agencies,  and  competing  and  conflicting  interests  of 
various stakeholders. While full and effective coordination and reforms 
in certain sectors may take time to evolve and needs further consensus 
building, the essential steps taken thus far will have a demonstrational 
effect in supporting infrastructure development in a coordinated manner 
in the coming years. 
  
Government Capacity. While the Government remains committed to 
reform objectives, the ability to translate that commitment into practical 
reform achievements is subject to available capacity within the different 
Government ministries and agencies. In several areas, progress has 
been slower than was anticipated by the Government when the IRSDP 
was agreed upon. This has typically been the result of low capacity, 
compounded  by  weak  coordination.  Mitigation  strategies  include 
realistic outputs and schedules based on likely reform progress, and 
continued provision of TA for capacity building. 
 
Poor Governance and Corruption. With the high stakes involved in 
large infrastructure projects, the IRSDP faces significant risks in the 
form of weak governance, collusion, and corruption, or lack of judicial 
capacity to enforce good-governance measures. Such problems have 
been common in the past in Indonesia. However, during the last few 
years the Government has considerably strengthened its anticorruption 
efforts.  Procurement  reforms  have  been  under  way  for  some  time, 
resulting in a competitive and transparent selection of bidders by the 
public sector. The PSP legal framework, adopted as part of the IRSDP, 
sets out clear rules for the selection of private sector sponsors for PPP 
projects. KKPPI is tasked with ensuring that tendering processes are 
fair  and  transparent.  The  president  of  Indonesia  has  considerably 
enhanced the profile and activities of the Anti-Corruption Commission 
and other law enforcement agencies. These steps are already having a 
significant impact.    
 
Macroeconomic Stability. Domestic macroeconomic volatility, adverse 
global events such as high oil and food prices, natural disasters, or the 
lack of sustained momentum on policy reforms could impede PSP. 
However, over the last few years, the Indonesian economy has been 
quite resilient to domestic and external shocks, and the Government’s 
macroeconomic policies have been sound. The country’s balance of 
payments  remains  in  strong  surplus,  foreign  reserve  levels  have 
reached $58 billion, and public debt as a share of GDP was 35% in 
2007 and was expected to decline to 30% in 2008. The banking sector 
appears sound, with moderate levels of nonperforming loans and high 
capital–adequacy ratios. As a result of good macroeconomic stability, 
Indonesia’s debt rating was upgraded to BB by Fitch in February 2008.

v 
Further deterioration in global economic conditions can make Indonesia 
vulnerable to sudden shifts in investor sentiment. 
 
Social Tensions. Tariff reforms are sensitive in any environment, and 
Indonesia is no exception. As the country is gradually moving away 
from  administered  prices  and  tariffs  for  infrastructure  products  and 
services, social tensions are inevitable. The Government has so far 
been  successful  in  reducing  such  tensions  by  the  two-pronged 
approach of (i) comprehensively socializing any planned price and tariff 
increases, and (ii) using the savings from the reduction in inefficient 
subsidies for direct poverty reduction, employment generation, and rural 
infrastructure development.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  Republic  of  Indonesia  for  the  Infrastructure  Reform  Sector  Development  Program 
(IRSDP) – Subprogram 2. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 
2.  Indonesia has seen increasingly strong economic expansion since recovering from the 
Asian financial crisis in 1997. In 2007, economic growth accelerated to a 10-year high of 6.3%, 
despite a slowing global economy. Domestic demand coupled with private investment has been 
a key driver of the recent economic growth. Poverty levels fell from over 16.5% in 2007 to 
15.5% in March 2008. These developments are even more surprising against the backdrop that 
Indonesia has also successfully recovered from a number of natural disasters, including the 
tsunami of December 2004 in Aceh. Despite the associated disaster relief expenditures, fiscal 
space  has  been  created  to  enable  a  resumption  of  the  pre-crisis  levels  of  infrastructure 
investments.  Indonesia’s  key  macroeconomic  indicators  for  2005–2008  are  summarized  in 
Table 1.

3.  As is the case with its Asian neighbors, Indonesia has been confronting significant 
inflationary pressures in 2008; inflation rose sharply from the beginning of the year to 12.1% 
year-on-year in September 2008. Despite the current global economic slowdown, Indonesia’s 
macroeconomic fundamentals held up reasonably well through the first 8 months of 2008. 
Indonesia’s balance of payments remained in strong surplus in 2007, with the current account 
recording a surplus of 2.5% of gross domestic product (GDP) in 2007. Exports jumped by 31% 
during the first 6 months of 2008 due to higher commodity prices and volume growth. However, 
reflecting strong domestic consumer and investment growth, imports more than doubled during 
this period, resulting in a small deficit in the current account in the second quarter of 2008. 
Foreign direct investment continued to remain strong in 2008, and reserves peaked at $60.5 
billion at the end of July 2008 before moderating to $52 billion at the middle of October 2008 as 
the  Government  attempted  to  stabilize  the  rupiah,  which  depreciated  from  an  average  of 
Rp9,150 to the dollar at the beginning of September to Rp10,600 to the dollar at the end of 
October, amid the volatility in the financial markets. Public debt continues to fall as a share of 
GDP; it was below 35% in 2007 and is likely to approach 30% in 2008. Total external debt is 
also falling, and is likely to be a little below 30% of GDP in 2008.   
 
4.  International oil prices generated significant pressure on the central government budget, 
but the overall fiscal position has remained sound. Recent trends in revenue from sources other 
than oil and gas have been especially favorable. However, energy subsidies are likely to make

up 4.7% of GDP and consume 20% of the 2008 budget. Driven by the increase in subsidies, 
measures have been proposed to cut nonpriority spending in line ministries, reduce subsidies 
for  electricity,  and  ration  kerosene  to  ensure  that  it  goes  only  to  the  poor.  In  May,  the 
Government  increased  fuel  prices  by  29%  across  the  board.  With  these  measures,  the 
Government’s latest tentative projection for 2008 indicates a deficit of around 1.3%, lower than 
the 1.9% deficit indicated at the start of the year. The Government is aware that, if the remaining 
subsidies  are  not  removed  over  the  medium  term,  they  would  crowd  out  higher-priority 
investments in the social and infrastructure sectors that are needed to sustain Indonesia's long-
term growth and development objectives. The Government recognizes the need for further 
steps towards reducing fuel subsidies.  
 
5.  The Government is pursuing a pro-growth agenda while pushing forward on broad 
structural and institutional reforms. Progress has been made on all fronts, although unevenly in 
some areas. Despite recent improvements, there is a continued need to improve the investment 
climate, public financial management, and service delivery mechanisms to the poor, which are 
supported by ADB’s development policy1 loan (DPSP) series. The IRSDP has allowed the 
Government to work with development partners in a flexible manner to implement critical high-
level policy dialogue and cross-cutting sector reforms that address constraints to infrastructure 
development while providing predictability of financial support.  
 
6.  The structure of Indonesia’s financial sector and exports implies Indonesia is better 
equipped than some of its neighbors to confront the global economic downturn. The banking 
sector has limited direct exposure to developments in US financial markets, relatively low levels 
of nonperforming loans (3.4% in August 2008), and high capital adequacy ratios (17.1% in 
August 2008). The country is also less exposed to external shocks than other countries in the 
region. At 50% of GDP, its trade share is relatively small, while the structure and destination of 
Indonesia’s exports offers some protection to its external sector from the current downturn. 
Almost  two-thirds  of  Indonesia’s  exports  are  commodities,  the  prices  of  which  have  been 
relatively strong but are now showing signs of weakness. Moreover, Indonesia’s exports have 
been increasingly moving towards economies in Asia and away from the US (12.3% of total 
exports in 2007) and European Union (14.5% of total exports in 2007). GDP growth is expected 
to moderate to 6.2% in 2008 and 6.0% in 2009 as export growth slows with the global economic 
downturn. Growth during this period will be sustained by robust domestic demand, especially 
investment and consumption demand. However, the possibility of a prolonged and more severe 
slump in the global economy holds considerable risks for Indonesia. On the other hand, further 
progress in structural reforms and removing infrastructure bottlenecks could improve growth 
projections. This makes the continuation of the IRSDP reform agenda to catalyze the required 
infrastructure investments even more vital.  
 
III.  THE SECTOR: PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Sector Description and Performance 
7.  For many years before the 1997 Asian financial crisis, Indonesia successfully used 
infrastructure development to support poverty reduction and economic development. However, 
the financial shock resulted in cancellation or suspension of many planned public and private 
infrastructure projects. Governments during 1998–2004 were burdened with the more urgent 
tasks  of  financial  sector  restructuring  and  fiscal  consolidation.  As  a  result,  infrastructure 
investments, which accounted for more than 6% of GDP before 1998, fell to a low of 2% in 2000 
and  fluctuated  around  3%  in  2001–2006,  reflecting  a  sharp  decline  in  public  and  private

8.  The availability of infrastructure services in rural areas, particularly outside Java and 
Bali,  is  well  below  the  national  average,  contributing  to  major  regional  disparities  in 
development. About 54% of rural villages are not connected to asphalt roads, and about one-
third of these lack year-round access even by four-wheel-drive vehicles. High transportation 
costs are a major cause of poverty in these communities. Only 15% of rural households have 
access to drinking water from piped or pumped sources, and just 21% have septic tanks for 
disposal of human waste. The low levels of access to safe drinking water and lack of adequate 
sanitation  facilities  contribute  to  high  incidence  of  waterborne  diseases  such  as  diarrhea, 
intestinal worms, and skin diseases. The incidence is higher among children and the elderly, 
and diarrhea is the second-largest cause of death and stunted growth among young children. 
Indonesia’s infant mortality rate is the highest among the Southeast Asian countries. 
 
9.    While the Asian financial crisis impeded development and growth in all of Southeast 
Asia, it has not been the sole reason for the poor state of infrastructure sectors in Indonesia. 
Supported by the economic boom prior to the crisis, investment decisions prior to the Asian 
crisis were made on the basis of political connections rather than being a clear and impartial 
judgment of the associated risks, benefits, and costs. As a result, the public sector absorbed a 
disproportionate share of the risks. In addition, no concerted effort was made to address the

various policy, legal, and institutional impediments facing the infrastructure sectors. After the 
crisis, Government efforts focused on risk mitigation by  renegotiating and canceling major 
infrastructure  contracts  signed  in  the  previous  years,  rather  than  on  removing  those 
impediments.  
 
10.    Following  Indonesia’s first  direct presidential  elections  in  October  2004,  the  current 
Government  set  the  following  ambitious  macroeconomic  targets  in  its  medium-term 
development program (RPJM) to be achieved by the end of its term in 2009: (i) accelerate GDP 
growth from 4.5% in 2003 to 7.6% (for an annual average of 6.6%), (ii) increase the investment-
GDP ratio from 20.5% in 2003 to 28.4%, (iii) reduce the unemployment rate from 9.7% in 2004 
to 5.1%, and (iv) halve the poverty rate from 16.6% in 2004 to 8.2%. From the outset, the 
Government identified the acceleration of infrastructure development as essential for achieving 
these macroeconomic targets, and gave high priority to increasing access to infrastructure 
services and improving the quality of these services. Since it was obvious that the estimated 
investment  requirements  would  far  exceed  the  available  public  sector  funding  (including 
multilateral and bilateral aid), the Government called for major private sector participation (PSP) 
to bridge the gap. Public–private partnerships (PPPs)—contractual arrangements between the 
public sector and a private sector company for the provision of an infrastructure service—were 
chosen as the preferred approach for increasing PSP.  
 
11.    In early 2005, the Government estimated that about $145 billion would be needed for 
infrastructure expansion during 2005–2009. In 2006, based on updated assessments and more 
realistic  forecasts  of  potential  investment  flows,  the  estimate  was  revised  down  to  about  
$65 billion, with $25 billion (38%) to come from the Government budget, $14 billion (22%) from 
domestic  banks  and  insurance  and  pension  funds,  $10  billion  (15%)  from  multilateral  and 
bilateral development partners, and $16 billion (25%) from domestic and foreign private sector 
investors. At this level, infrastructure investments would again reach about 5%–6% of GDP, 
considered to be the minimum required to restore pre-crisis levels of infrastructure provision and 
support the RPJM targets. 
 
12.    The Government has been aware of the urgent need to improve the investment climate 
through policy reforms that would (i) liberalize markets and allow competition from new entrants, 
(ii) strengthen regulatory arrangements, (iii) introduce tariff regimes based on full cost recovery 
or provide compensation to meet public service obligations (PSOs), and (iv) establish effective 
mechanisms for dispute resolution. At the Indonesia Infrastructure Summit (IIS) in Jakarta in 
January 2005, President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono led high-level Government officials in 
expressing  the  political  will  to  accelerate  infrastructure  development  and  proceed  with  the 
necessary reforms. At the subsequent Indonesia Infrastructure Conference and Exhibition in 
November 2006, this commitment was reiterated, and a number of reforms were presented that 
established the policy, legal, regulatory, and institutional framework for PPPs.  
 
13.  At the Consultative Group on Indonesia meeting in January 2005, the Government 
asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide medium-term support for infrastructure 
reforms and thereby help implement the RPJM. This request led to an intensification of ADB’s 
policy dialogue with the Government and other development partners. For the IIS, the three

infrastructure sectors, and on reforms needed to address these. Subsequently, in May 2005 the 
governments of Indonesia and Japan jointly adopted the strategic investment action plan, which 
included many infrastructure-related measures, to improve the investment climate. Building on

B.  Issues and Opportunities 
1.  Issues 
15.  All sectors lag behind Indonesia’s neighbors in terms of service coverage, and their 
investment requirements are much higher than the public sector can mobilize on its own. This 
underlines  the  need  for  prioritization,  so  that  public  sector  resources  are  used  for  basic 
infrastructure such as rural roads, rural electrification, and water supply and sanitation in rural 
and low-income urban areas, i.e., interventions of a noncommercial nature that have a strong 
impact on poverty reduction. Financing from multilateral and bilateral development partners 
should also be used for this purpose. The development partners also play an important role in 
assisting the Government to create an attractive environment for greater PSP, which is crucial 
for meeting the massive investment requirements, and in attracting private sector investment for 
commercially viable PPP projects. The IRSDP is helping Indonesia realize the potential for PSP 
and  leverage  public  sector  resources  to  reduce  service  coverage  gaps  by  removing  the 
impediments and constraints described in Section 2 below and in Appendix 2.  
 
2.  Legal and Regulatory Impediments 
16.  Inadequate Cross-Sector Framework for Private Sector Participation. To revive 
private investments in infrastructure, an effective legal framework is critical. The presidential 
decree issued in the wake of the 1997 Asian financial crisis did not fulfill this purpose.6 Although 
it  defined  PSP  and  called  for  the  selection  of  private  sector  sponsors  through  open  and 
transparent tendering, the decree adopted a simplistic approach and left many critical questions 
unanswered on PPP scope, implementation, performance norms, tariffs, and dispute resolution. 
In the absence of an overall infrastructure law, a replacement of this decree by presidential 
regulation 67/2005 has been considered the best way to provide an adequate legal framework.  
 
17.  Complex  Sector-Specific  Legal  and  Regulatory  Framework.  The  legal  and 
regulatory framework in Indonesia’s infrastructure sectors is complex. Each sector has its own 
law, and the division of responsibilities for the five principal functions—policy making, sector 
planning, regulation, contracting, and operating—differs greatly. While the line ministries in

regulators independent, and (iii) the need for equal opportunities for private sector operators. 
 
3.  Resource Constraints Impeding Public and Private Investments 
18.  Lack of Focus on and Resources for Project Preparation. An important prerequisite 
for PSP is adequacy and consistency of information needed for investment decisions. This has 
been constrained by lack of resources for sector planning, and line ministries and contracting 
agencies not focusing on project preparation. Before the Asian financial crisis, Indonesia had a 
well-established  system  for  preparing  annual  and  medium-term  sector  plans  that  identified 
targets for infrastructure provision and developed investment plans for achieving the targets. 
However, due to lack of resources for plan preparation—and, more importantly, for actual public 
investment  in  infrastructure—planning  capacity  in  some  sectors  has  been  eroded.  Sector 
development plans describing long-term physical expansion, and sector blueprints outlining a 
long-term  vision  in  terms  of  restructuring  and  competition,  are  an  essential  element  in 
investment decisions. To prepare and regularly update such plans and blueprints, the planning 
functions and capacity of line ministries need to be strengthened in accordance with the gradual 
shift in the role of the Government from service provider to policy maker, planner, coordinator, 
and facilitator. Lack of capacity and resources and the absence of a systematic process have 
also led to lack of attention to project preparation. While the budget system does allow line 
ministries  and  agencies  to  obtain  some  resources  for  preparing  feasibility  studies,  the 
widespread view is that, for PPP projects, this work should be done by the private sector 
sponsors.  Once  projects  are  identified  and  some  preparation  done,  the  critical  steps  of 
procurement and transaction execution also generally suffer from resource constraints. Given 
the high degree of autonomy of line ministries, strong central coordination is needed to ensure a 
consistent approach to PSP across infrastructure sectors and efficient use of available funds. 
 
19.    Lack  of  a  Sound  Risk  Management  Framework.  In  the  first  half  of  the  1990s, 
unsolicited  project  proposals  from  politically connected  private  sector  parties  created  large 
public sector liabilities, particularly in the power sector, that were highlighted by the 1997 
financial crisis. The subsequent administrations therefore became reluctant to offer support to 
private sector investors. More recently, the Government has recognized the importance of 
adequate  risk  mitigation  and  sharing  to  attract  major  PSP.  A  sound  investment  climate, 
supported  by  reduced  investor  perception  of  corruption,  would  be  the  best  risk  mitigation 
mechanism. This would entail continuous and sustained policy reforms that lead to a stable 
macroeconomic  environment,  well-functioning  judicial  system,  independent  and  technically 
sound regulation, full cost recovery in infrastructure services (or a well-targeted output-based 
subsidy where the full cost recovery would make such services unaffordable), and open access 
in the infrastructure sectors. During the transition before these ideal conditions are achieved and

that are not under their control. The principal lesson is that the previous practice of blanket

other important lesson is that risk allocation should not be rigid. Risks should gradually be 
transferred  from  the  public  sector  to  private  investors  as  conditions  improve,  until  market 
instruments rather than government guarantees can be used for risk hedging. 
 
20.    Inadequate Cost Recovery. Given the multiplicity of agencies involved, and with SOEs 
playing a key role in many sectors, tariffs for infrastructure services are usually administered. 
Most notably for power, oil and gas, and air transport, national or local parliamentary approval or 
presidential regulations with parliamentary consensus are needed for tariff increases. Despite a 
series of increases in electricity tariffs, domestic oil prices, and transportation tariffs since 2000, 
full cost recovery has not yet been achieved, mainly because of escalating international oil 
prices. Adopting the full cost recovery principle is essential to encouraging greater PSP and 
enhancing efficiency in the allocation of resources. At the same time, the ability of the poor to 
pay for infrastructure services needs to be considered. 
 
21.    Failure to Achieve Equity and Efficiency in Public Service Obligations. Full cost 
recovery can only be achieved gradually. Even in the long term, low-income customers may not 
be able to pay the required tariffs for infrastructure services, and there are limitations on cross 
subsidization by more affluent customer categories. The current situation differs from sector to 
sector, with no uniform PSO approach. Loss-making port and airport facilities are either cross 
subsidized in SOE portfolios or are left to line ministries to operate and finance from their 
budget. In the power sector, the State Electricity Corporation (PLN) receives a huge annual 
subsidy from the Government budget, as the current electricity tariffs are below PLN’s cost of 
supply in all consumer categories. Low tariffs for water supply result in the poor financial 
condition and high indebtedness of the regional water supply enterprises (PDAMs) that are 
owned by local governments. The Government also provides annual subsidies for the so-called 
pioneer services in bus, railway, ship, and air transport. In the telecommunications sector, a 
portion of revenues of private companies is retained for subsidized rural services. To achieve 
greater PSP and higher efficiencies in PSO provision, a consistent cross-sector PSO framework 
is needed. While the public sector will continue to have an important role in delivering many 
noncommercial services, innovative approaches allowing PSP could include output-based aid 
that is explicit, targeted, and driven by the service provider’s performance.  
 
22.    Shallow Domestic Financing Modalities. Banking plays a dominant role within the 
financial system. Capital markets have grown in importance, but long-term debt issuance has 
until recently been limited to government bonds. The issuance of corporate bonds has been 
gradually growing, but only a small portion originates from SOEs operating in the infrastructure 
sectors. On the supply side, contractual savings institutions such as pension and insurance 
companies have traditionally invested predominantly in government bonds or bank deposits. 
While the Government estimates that domestic financial institutions can meet about 20% of the 
infrastructure funding requirements, concerted reforms are needed to help mobilize domestic 
resources of this magnitude. Domestic financing would help reduce the currency mismatch and 
the extent of government guarantees for PPP projects. The Government needs to facilitate the 
development of local financial and capital markets by (i) enabling insurance firms and pension 
funds to finance infrastructure, (ii) deepening the bond market, (iii) setting up sound credit-rating 
agencies, (iv) establishing dedicated infrastructure funds, and (v) allowing regional governments 
to borrow for infrastructure in local markets.

4.  Other Constraints Impeding Infrastructure Development 
23.    Weak Legal, Regulatory, and Implementation Framework for Land Acquisition. 
Land acquisition problems have impeded a number of infrastructure projects, particularly toll 
roads. Until 2005, land acquisition was governed by the old Basic Agrarian Law and presidential 
regulation 55/1993 on Land Acquisition for Public Infrastructure. While providing a legal basis, 
these documents failed to balance the need to protect social safeguards with regard to the need 
for expeditious provision of land or right-of-way access for infrastructure development. As the 
cost of land is generally high, an effective mechanism to finance land acquisition in a timely 
manner and prevent speculation is essential. In many countries, land acquisition for large 
infrastructure PPP projects is done by the public sector as its contribution to project investment 
costs.  
 
24.    Lack  of  Clarity  Due  to  Regional  Autonomy.  Decentralization,  while  devolving 
considerable authority and autonomy to local governments, has complicated matters related to 
infrastructure  development.  Until  recently,  responsibility  for  the  provision  of  infrastructure 
services and the role of local-government-owned enterprises (BUMDs) has not been clearly 
articulated. Local governments, with control over local infrastructure, have not been provided 
with adequate funds and most lack the necessary capacity.  
 
25.    Safety, Security, and Asset Maintenance. Access and connectivity are vital in the 
Indonesian  archipelago.  Adherence  to  safety  and  security  standards  for  various  modes  of 
transportation is equally critical. The Government recently began adopting safety and security 
norms,  and  establishing  the  necessary  institutional  mechanisms.  In  the  road  sector, 
maintenance gets varying levels of attention across the country, with national and provincial 
roads reasonably well preserved but district and urban roads in poor condition due to gross 
underspending on maintenance. Safety norms for road use and vehicle overloading are only 
slowly emerging, and enforcement is weak. Safety is also an issue for air and sea transportation 
due  to  disparities  in  the  adoption  of  safety  norms  across  the  country  and  ineffective 
enforcement.  
 
5.  Summary of Constraints and Impediments 
26.    Poor Governance and Resource Constraints. In the aftermath of the 1997 financial 
crisis, four facets of governance that impede infrastructure development have emerged: (i) 
absence of sound PSP policies and framework, (ii) opaqueness in tendering, and corruption and 
rent-seeking during implementation affecting both public and private sectors, (iii) inequality in 
access  to  opportunities  by  the  public  and  private  sector,  and  (iv)  weak  cross-sector 
coordination. The impact of poor governance has been aggravated by the following fiscal and 
other resource-related impediments affecting public and private investments in infrastructure: (i) 
declining  institutional  capacity  for  sector  planning,  (ii)  lack  of  focus  on,  and  inadequate 
resources allocated to, project preparation, (iii) lack of risk sharing, (iv) lack of cost recovery, 
which threatens the financial viability of projects, (v) inability of the public sector to finance land 
acquisition, and (vi) lack of long-term financial intermediation. Appendix 3 shows links between 
the various constraints and impediments addressed by the IRSDP.  
 
6.  Lessons  
27.    In terms of lending modalities, the Government has shown strong preference for policy-
based budget support. ADB has responded to this preference. During 2005–2007, program 
loans accounted for $2.0 billion, or over 70%, of ADB’s total lending commitments of about $2.8 
billion. At this magnitude, it has been imperative that lessons borne out by past operations of 
this type be taken into account. The role of program lending as a vehicle for economic growth

9
and poverty reduction was examined in several studies,8 leading to the following principal 
conclusions and recommendations: (i) policy frameworks were often complex and unrealistic, (ii) 
a high degree of formal compliance with conditions did not necessarily lead to high-quality 
compliance in terms of reform implementation and sustainability, (iii) political economy factors 
such as the commitment to (and timing of) reforms, the extent of the underlying problems, 
appreciation by the public of the seriousness of these problems, and length of the government 
term, were critical, (iv) broader stakeholder participation was vital to obtain adequate buy-in and 
mitigate vested interests, (v) mere adoption of policies and passage of laws was not enough—
their implementation was equally important, (vi) policy measures should focus on the main 
objectives  of  the  program,  and  each  action  should  be  specific  and  directly  related  to  the 
objectives, (vii) to provide the necessary flexibility, program design should allow not only the 
standard multitranche operations, but also options with a single tranche, floating tranches, and a 
program cluster, (viii) reforms should be phased in and fully aligned with the country’s broader 
medium-term development agenda, and (ix) funding agencies should harmonize and coordinate 
their policy advice and operations. 
 
28.  A program cluster modality with three single-tranche subprograms anchored on the 
Government’s medium-term reform agenda (RPJM) has been adopted since the start of the 
IRSDP series. ADB’s experience with single-tranche program loans in Indonesia has been 
effective, as the loan disbursement is based on a range of up-front actions taken by the 
Government in the core areas of infrastructure. This approach provides the flexibility to an 
emerging middle-income country such as Indonesia to build consensus for reforms resulting in a 
natural progression from actions to desired outcomes.   
 
29.  With one exception, the above lessons and recommendations have been reflected in 
the IRSDP design and implementation. Because of the wide range of infrastructure sectors and 
the need to cover several thematic areas in each of them, it has not been possible to design a 
simple  policy  matrix  that  would  ensure  the  desired  outcome  of  increasing  infrastructure 
investments to 6%–7% of GDP. Incorporating the other lessons, the IRSDP supports the RPJM, 
its policy-based component is anchored on the Government’s Infrastructure Policy Package to 
ensure strong ownership, and it has been formulated and implemented in close cooperation with 
JICA and the World Bank. The general public experiences the infrastructure bottlenecks and the 
poor quality of infrastructure services on a daily basis. Consequently, the majority of people 
support the reforms, as demonstrated by their acceptance of the steep oil price increases in 
2005 and 2008. Nevertheless, the reform agenda is broad and challenging as it covers all 
infrastructure sectors, and some vested interests oppose parts of it.  
 
30.    To allow the necessary flexibility in reform implementation, the program cluster model 
consisting  of  three  single-tranche  subprograms  has  been  adopted  for  the  IRSDP.  The 
successful implementation of subprograms 1 and 2 has confirmed the advantages of this model. 
Despite its large scope and complexity, the IRSDP has proven to be manageable and the 
Government’s ownership of it remains strong. This has been attributable to the fact that, unlike 
multitranche programs that provide an incentive to implement agreed future reforms in several 
stages within a predetermined time frame, single-tranche programs provide an incentive for 
agreed completed reforms. This structure removes the rigidity of firm deadlines for actions 
outside the Government’s control, such as legislative approvals, and helps deflect criticisms that 
the reforms are a result of external pressure. The subprogram 2 and 3 loans have been 
submitted to ADB’s Board for approval only after the agreed actions had been completed (rather 
than up front as in the case of the second and third tranches of multitranche programs). The 
reform  agenda  and  its  timing  have  been  periodically  reviewed  in  light  of  the  actual

IV.  THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
38.    By enhancing infrastructure provision and access, the IRSDP aims to improve the 
investment climate in Indonesia and support timely realization of the Government’s medium-
term macroeconomic goals articulated in the RPJM, in particular achieving average annual GDP 
growth of 6%–7% during 2005–2009 and sustaining such growth thereafter. This will enable the 
Government to reduce poverty and boost job creation. The expected outcome of the IRSDP is 
accelerated infrastructure development through major PSP and mobilization and allocation of 
additional public sector resources. Appendix 6 presents the Government’s letter of development 
policy, which reiterates its commitment to infrastructure reforms, along with updated policy 
matrixes for the IRSDP and IDPL, which detail these parallel operations and show their current 
status. 
 
B.  Scope

C.  Important Features 
41.  The IRSDP has a number of important features. First, its overall design is fully in line 
with the Government’s medium-term development growth vision, as articulated in the RPJM, 
and the Government’s infrastructure reform agenda, as formulated in the infrastructure policy 
package. Second, designed as a program cluster consisting of three subprograms, the IRSDP 
provides the necessary flexibility to an emerging middle-income country like Indonesia that is 
going through democratic and political transition for it to build consensus for reforms among 
stakeholders with competing interests. It also ensures continuity of reforms resulting in a natural 
progression from actions to desired outcomes. 
  
42.  Third,  the  IRSDP  helps  address  investment  climate  impediments,  a  major  area  of

(i)  Strategic cross-sector reforms will result in 
(a)  an improved policy, legal, and institutional framework for PSP anchored 
on good-governance principles; 
(b)  an  improved  coordination  mechanism  for  ministries  and  agencies

2.  Strategic Cross-Sector Reforms 
46.  Legal Framework to Promote Private Sector Participation. Under subprogram 1, the 
Government issued presidential regulation 67/2005 on Cooperation between the Government 
and Business Entities in the Provision of Infrastructure to establish a clear and predictable 
environment  within  which  private  investors  would  operate.  Presidential  regulation  67/2005 
defined two forms of PSP, namely, partnership and licensing agreements. PPP projects can be 
identified and prepared either by the Government or the private sector, but the sponsors must

16    
be selected through open and transparent tendering. Tariffs should be set at full cost-recovery 
level. If this exceeds the ability of consumers to pay, the Government must compensate for the 
difference with a PSO subsidy. Risks should be allocated to the party that is best able to 
manage and control them. 
 
47.  With these principles, presidential regulation 67/2005 has proved to be a cornerstone of 
infrastructure reforms. However, during its implementation under subprogram 2, the lack of 
clarity in some provisions and gaps in others has become evident. Through the TA (footnote 9), 
ADB has therefore supported the revision of clauses related to the definition of contracting 
agency, form and scope of Government support, definition of financial closure, responsibility for 
public consultations, role of local governments, and number of re-bidding rounds. There have 
also been proposals to amend the procedure and rules for selecting private sector partners, in 
the belief that it would expedite transaction execution. To avoid diluting the principles of project 
quality, transparency, and competition, ADB and the World Bank have held intensive policy 
dialogue with the Government such that the revision of presidential regulation 67/2005 will 
maintain the fundamental principles. 
 
48.    Institutional  and  Coordination  Arrangements  for  Private  Sector  Participation. 
Presidential regulation 42/2005 enhanced the ability of the interministerial National Committee 
for  the  Acceleration  of  Infrastructure  Provision  (KKPPI)15  to  fulfill  its  role  in  (i)  formulating 
infrastructure strategies and policies, (ii) coordinating and supervising their implementation by 
the line ministries and local governments, (iii) formulating PSO policy for infrastructure services, 
and (iv) solving problems that impede infrastructure development, in particular PPP projects. To 
ensure  effective  functioning  of  KKPPI,  its  secretariat,  headed  by  the  deputy  minister  for 
infrastructure and regional development in CMEA (in charge of administrative matters and 
stakeholder consultations) and the deputy minister for infrastructure affairs in BAPPENAS (in 
charge of technical matters), needed sustained capacity building and advisory support. 
 
49.    For about 2 years under subprogram 2, ADB provided the required support to the 
BAPPENAS part of the KKPPI secretariat through TA (footnote 9), while the CMEA part has 
been supported by the World Bank’s Private Provision of Infrastructure Technical Assistance 
loan. Coordination of the two parts has been improved by (i) the creation of the positions of an 
executive secretary and administrative manager filled by nongovernment staff who reviewed the 
structure  and  operations  of  the  KKPPI  secretariat,  (ii)  the  demarcation  of  responsibilities 
between BAPPENAS and CMEA, and (iii) the work program for KKPPI. Based on this review, a 
number of measures related to institutional arrangements, standard operating procedures, and

central PPP unit under the KKPPI secretariat and PPP nodes in the line ministries has been 
partly developed. There are already PPP nodes in some line ministries that are responsible for 
project preparation and transaction execution. The network will be completed and become 
operational under subprogram 3.

focusing on short-term investments and operation and maintenance, has been updated with 
JICA’s assistance. To implement the revitalization program, the Government has allocated 
Rp19 trillion ($2.1 billion) to KAI for a planned joint venture with private companies to transport 
cement,  coal,  and  shipping  containers  in  Sumatra,  and  as  the  start-up  capital  for  a  new 
subsidiary  which  will  double  the  capacity  of  the  commuter  rail  service  in  Jakarta  and  its 
environs.  
 
69.  Passenger fares for economy-class travel are set periodically by MOT, putting more 
emphasis on ability to pay than cost recovery. Other passenger fares and all freight fares can be 
set by KAI subject to MOT’s endorsement. Under subprogram 3, an MOT regulation on the 
formula for tariff calculation aimed at full cost recovery, taking into account PSO subsidy, will be 
issued. Such transparent tariff and PSO arrangements are necessary to encourage PSP. JICA 
is assisting KAI in improving railway operation and maintenance so that it will be able to meet 
the challenge of competition with private service providers. 
 
70.  Oil and Gas. The Government has given high priority to, and showed remarkable 
political courage in, reducing fuel subsidies that have imposed a heavy burden on the budget, 
disproportionately benefited the middle class and the rich, and distorted the energy mix. In 2005 
under subprogram 1, the domestic prices of oil products except kerosene were first increased 
by an average of 49%. This was followed by bringing the prices for industrial users, accounting 
for 37% of total consumption, to international levels and, after intensive socialization efforts, 
raising prices of the remaining oil products by an additional 126%. To mitigate the social impact 
of these unprecedented measures, the Government announced a major package of direct

22    
subsidies to the poor. The Government also made clear its intention to complete the fuel 
subsidy removal in the next few years and let domestic oil prices follow international prices 
thereafter. However, the sharp price increases led to a temporary slowdown in economic growth 
and an upsurge in inflation. For macroeconomic and political reasons, the Government decided 
to defer further price adjustments until after the next elections in 2009. The recent escalation of 
international oil prices made a reconsideration of this decision unavoidable. In May 2008, 
domestic oil prices were increased by an average of 29%.23 The price increases have been 
complemented by several measures to influence consumer behavior and stop diversion of the 
still highly subsidized kerosene to other uses: (i) issuance of control cards to households limiting 
their monthly kerosene consumption, (ii) conversion from kerosene to liquefied petroleum gas, 
with free distribution of gas stoves and cylinders to households,24 and (iii) smart cards for 
gasoline limiting the quantity purchased per vehicle at the subsidized price.  
 
71.  Given the country's large reserves, natural gas can play a much more important role 
domestically. Presidential regulation 5/2006 on National Energy Policy calls for a minimum 
share of 30% for natural gas in Indonesia’s energy mix by 2025, compared to less than 20% for 
oil. To move towards this target, an oil and gas sector blueprint has been prepared and a 
master plan for the natural gas pipeline network already completed under subprogram 2. In 
response to the Constitutional Court’s ruling on Oil and Gas Law 22/2001, the Ministry of 
Energy and Mineral Resources (MEMR) has drafted two regulations, which set the domestic 
market obligation for gas producers at 25% and outline pricing principles. Another impetus to 
the domestic use of gas has come from the new law 30/2007 on Energy and the related 
Government regulations on energy conservation, renewable energy, and supply and utilization 
of energy, all of which promote greater PSP. As investments in the country’s large reserves of 
coal-bed methane have been limited due to lack of policy and legal clarity, guidelines for the 
exploration  and  production  of  this  resource  have  been  issued  through  MEMR  regulation 
33/2006. BPH Migas, established as a regulatory body for downstream oil and gas activities and 
a contracting agency for transmission and distribution of natural gas, is fully operational with 
about 70 permanent and 30 contractual staff. Its main objectives are to ensure supply security 
of oil products and increase domestic utilization of natural gas.  
 
72.  Power. The annulment by the Constitutional Court of law 20/2002 on Electricity, which 
provided  a  progressive  long-term  vision  in  terms  of  unbundling,  independent  regulation, 
competition, and PSP, was a serious setback for power sector reforms. To remove the legal 
uncertainty caused by this ruling that automatically led to reenactment of the previous law 
15/1985 on Electricity, Government regulations 3/2005 and 26/2006 were issued as an interim 
solution until a new law was in place. While giving the principal authority for power supply to 
PLN, the regulations allow purchase of electricity by PLN from independent power producers 
(IPPs). Under subprogram 2, a new electricity law has been drafted by MEMR and submitted to 
Parliament, where it has been undergoing extensive deliberations and stakeholder consultations 
to reach a consensus on how to reduce PLN’s monopoly and increase competition, while 
retaining control of the sector through stronger planning and regulation. The draft law allows 
competition  only  in  power  generation  but  it  provides  for  more  than  one  utility,  so  that 
regionalization of power supply is possible. In anticipation of this change, the Ministry of State-
Owned Enterprises has prepared a policy paper on PLN’s restructuring that envisages the 
creation of regional subsidiaries and the conversion of PLN from an operator to an investment 
holding company. The first step in implementing the paper’s recommendation has been taken 
by restructuring PLN’s board of directors in March 2008 and tasking it with the establishment of

73.  PLN has an installed capacity of about 24,000 megawatts (MW), but with demand 
growing at almost 10% per year, its reserve margin has decreased to 20% from the safe level of 
30%. This decrease, combined with derating of older power plants and problems with natural 
gas supply, has recently led to widespread load shedding. PLN’s 10-year power development 
plan, updated under subprogram 2, is anchored on a fast-track public sector program of 10,000 
MW of coal-fired plants and an IPP program of another 10,000 MW using coal, geothermal 
energy, and renewable energy resources. Both programs are under way, but it will take several 
years to remove the capacity constraints and displace oil-based generation. Under subprogram 
3, with support from the World Bank PLN will formulate and start to implement a new rural 
electrification strategy to meet the Government’s target of 90% access by 2020.   
 
74.  Unlike domestic oil prices, there has been no uniform increase in electricity tariffs since 
2003, when the average tariff was brought to the pre-crisis level of $0.068 per kilowatt-hour 
(kWh), with only the first 30 kWh of the monthly consumption of small consumers subsidized 
through a lifeline rate of $0.018/kWh. Because of the escalating oil prices and significant share 
of oil-fired power plants in PLN’s generation mix, the fuel cost alone now exceeds the average 
tariff,  and  all  consumer  categories  are  subsidized.  The  total  electricity  subsidy  in  2008  is 
estimated at Rp60 trillion ($6.5 billion). PLN is having ongoing discussions with large industries 
to seek increased payments in return for more reliable power supply. In April 2008, the so-called 
disincentive scheme, with unsubsidized tariffs for consumption above a certain threshold, has 
been introduced for large residential customers, but the Government is reluctant to go beyond 
that and compound the effects of the domestic oil price increases with major across-the-board 
electricity tariff adjustments. Nevertheless, the Government recognizes that restoring PLN’s 
financial viability in the medium term is crucial to enhancing its creditworthiness and avoiding 
requests by IPPs and their lenders for government guarantees against this off-take risk. In the 
interim, the Government has been providing assurances for new IPP projects by referring to its 
PSO policy for SOEs and MOF’s regulations on PLN subsidy.   
 
75.  Telecommunications. This infrastructure sector is more advanced in terms of reforms 
than the others and is naturally progressing, without much external intervention, towards ever 
greater PSP. As in other countries, this is attributable to the technological advances driving the 
sector,  as  well  as  to  the  fact  that  its  tariffs  are  less  affected  by  political  and  social 
considerations. The two major enterprises—Telkom and Indosat—are listed on the Jakarta and 
New  York  stock  exchanges,  the  Indonesian  Telecommunications  Regulatory  Body  (BRTI) 
established under the Ministry of Communications and Informatics is fully operational, and 
regulation 8/2006 on interconnection has allowed a move from revenue sharing to a cost-based 
approach for tariff setting.  
 
76.  Under subprogram 2, the scope of the sector blueprint has been broadened to reflect 
the convergence of information and communications technology (ICT). The blueprint, named the 
ICT Infrastructure Convergence Road Map, aims at creating a more competitive market for the 
entire spectrum of these services (voice, data, and broadcasting), and will be implemented 
during  2009–2014.  As  part  of  the  move  from  the  Telkom  and  Indosat  duopoly  to  more 
competition, a third provider of international connections—Bakrie Telekom—has been selected 
in  a  “beauty  contest”25  of  four  domestic  candidates,  based  on  their  subscriber  base,  and 
international  and  domestic  links.  A  similar  contest  is  under  preparation  for  long-distance

operators to set their basic tariffs for fixed lines, and ministerial regulation 9/2008 does the same

77.  Water  Supply  and  Sanitation.  The  IRSDP  has  supported  the  formulation  and 
implementation of policies on community and institution-based provision of water supply and 
sanitation services to more effectively address access and quality issues in service delivery. 
The  Water  Resources  Law  7/2004  and  Government  regulation  16/2005  on  Water  Supply 
established the legal framework for PSP by clarifying its forms,27 ending PDAM monopolies, 
eliminating the need for local parliament approval of water tariff increases, and calling for the 
establishment  of  the  National  Water  Supply  System  Development  Supporting  Agency 
(BPPSPAM)  under  MPW.  During  subprogram  2,  MPW  regulation  20/2006  on  policy  and 
strategy for water supply development has been issued that aims at increasing the current 
connection ratios of about 42% in urban areas and 9% in rural areas to meet the Millennium 
Development Goal target of halving by 2015 the proportion of people without sustainable access 
to safe drinking water. The two-pronged strategy relies on PDAMs and private concessionaires 
for expanding water supply and sanitation in urban areas and a community-driven development 
approach in rural villages. The latter is supported by the Government’s Self-Help Program for 
Community Empowerment (PNPM Mandiri) that provides grants for small facilities in all villages 
in Indonesia during 2007–2012.28 The legal framework has been completed through MPW 
regulations on water supply provision (with detailed guidelines for PDAMs and private sector 
operators) and solid-waste management, as well as by passing law 18/2008 on Municipal 
Waste Management that promotes the "3Rs" principle (reduce, reuse, and recycle).  
 
78.  BPPSPAM is an advisory body whose responsibilities include helping formulate sector 
policy  and  strategy,  setting  operational  standards  for  water  supply,  setting  and  evaluating 
service  standards  and  performance  of  PDAMs,  making  recommendations  on  involving 
cooperatives and the private sector in water supply, and settling disputes. Under subprogram 2, 
BPPSPAM has completed the mapping of managerial, technical, and financial performance for 
306 out of 335 PDAMs,29 and published the results in a book and on its website. Using criteria 
such as operating ratio, debt–equity ratio, customer structure, number of employees per 1,000 
customers, water losses, and operating hours, the PDAMs have been classified into three 
categories: (i) healthy PDAMs (79, or 26%), (ii) less healthy PDAMs (114, or 37%), and (iii) sick 
PDAMs (113, or 37%). The mapping will be updated every year to exert pressure on PDAMs to 
improve their performance through enhanced managerial autonomy, technical capacity building, 
cost recovery tariffs, improved revenue collection, better financial management and accounting, 
unaccounted-for water reduction, stronger customer orientation, and mergers of small nonviable 
PDAMs. 
 
79.  An important prerequisite for improving performance of PDAMs so that they can expand 
service coverage is debt resolution. MOF regulation 107/2005 allowed restructuring of PDAM 
debt totaling Rp6.7 trillion, but progress was very slow. A more radical restructuring program

VI.  PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS  
A.  Expected Impacts 
100.  The key economic, social, and institutional benefits expected from the IRSDP are 
 
(i)  sustained progress in meeting the Government’s medium-term economic growth 
objectives, as articulated in the RPJM for 2004–2009; 
(ii)  improvements in the investment climate, to be demonstrated by sound policy, 
legal, and institutional frameworks in the infrastructure sectors; 
(iii)  greater potential for PSP, and a more systematic approach for implementing PPP 
transactions; 
(iv)  preparation and implementation of quality infrastructure projects in a transparent 
and  expedient  manner,  resulting  in  (a)  improved  availability  and  quality  of 
infrastructure services; (b) a boost to Indonesia’s competitiveness with regard to 
its regional neighbors; and (c) lower poverty incidence, through direct as well as 
indirect transmission channels; 
(v)  sustained engagement by ADB in the policy dialogue with the Government on the 
direction  and  content  of,  and  strategies  for,  its  economic,  structural,  and 
institutional reform agenda in the broader area of investment climate; the IRSDP 
provides for policy continuity and consistency in areas where ADB has been 
actively involved; and 
(vi)  aid harmonization and parallel financing by the key development partners around 
a common policy framework and dialogue, and the positive externalities resulting 
from such a joint endorsement of the Government’s reform agenda. 
 
101.  Institutional. The IRSDP is strengthening the key institutions dealing with infrastructure 
development  in  Indonesia.  At  the  national  level,  KKPPI,  its  secretariat,  and  the  RMU  are 
evolving  into  strong  institutions  that  coordinate  central  support  for  PSP  in  infrastructure 
development. The PPP unit at the central level will provide further support for the development 
of infrastructure projects covering all sectors. Within each infrastructure sector, the regulatory 
bodies will be strengthened over the medium term by enhancing their autonomy, clarifying their 
mandate, and providing adequate resources for their operations. The capacity to prepare and 
execute  bankable  projects  is  being  systematically  built  up.  The  Government  is  developing

32    
institutions such as the IIFF and Guarantee Fund to support infrastructure financing. In addition 
to this, the existing domestic financial institutions are being strengthened.  
 
102.  Social. The IRSDP’s main contribution is to improve the investment climate and thereby 
contribute directly to poverty reduction through greater access to markets, and economic and 
employment opportunities. The policy reforms are intended to lead to increased infrastructure 
investments by the public and private sectors. On balance, the poverty and social impacts of the 
reforms and ensuing investments will be positive, through the benefits of induced economic 
growth  and  the  improved  provision  of  infrastructure  services.  The  May  2008  increases  in 
domestic oil prices have freed up additional funds for more pro-poor spending. The Government 
is reviewing tariff policies in all sectors and adopting tariff regimes that are in line with cost-
recovery principles. At the same time, the impact of tariff increases on the poor is mitigated 
through appropriate measures, and the PSO framework is being strengthened to effectively 
deliver essential infrastructure services. The adoption of market-based pricing promotes PSP, 
which  in  turn  leads  to  greater  tax  and  non-tax  revenues  and  additional  employment 
opportunities.  Potential  negative  impacts  include  social  dislocation  and  inadequate 
compensation for land acquisition. The Government has established the Land Working Group to 
deal with issues of land zoning and purchase of land in anticipation of future infrastructure 
developments. The Government is also considering alternative approaches to provide speedy 
compensation and enhance administrative accountability through transparent dispute resolution 
mechanisms. Overall, the IRSDP is leading to significant social benefits. Appendix 10 presents 
a summary poverty reduction and social strategy. 
 
103.  Economic. The IRSDP reforms are expected to have short- and long-term net benefits. 
These include a reduced fiscal burden from the gradual fuel subsidy removal and improved cost 
recovery in all infrastructure sectors. The PSO policy framework provides the basis for better 
targeting of infrastructure service provision, connectivity, and access for low-income groups. 
The PDAM debt restructuring program will reverse the decline in service quality and coverage of 
water supply and sanitation. PLN restructuring and tariff revisions will lower the Government 
subsidy while improving PLN’s efficiency. Passage of the Law on Electricity will pave the way for 
medium- to long-term improvements in electricity supply and efficiency as the conditions for 
private sector investment improve and subsequent investment in generation increases, in turn 
improving the overall investment climate. The introduction of independent transport and utility 
regulators in the longer term will remove government interference in utility operations and 
pricing, providing the basis for improved efficiencies. Economic benefits are expected to accrue 
from improved quality of existing roads through better road maintenance and vehicle load 
control and expanded road networks, by improving access to markets and other forms of 
connectivity, and lowering vehicle operating costs. Major general economic benefits will accrue 
to  the  entire  Indonesian  population  through  the  expanded  scope  and  improved  quality  of 
infrastructure services. 
  
104.  The rigorous project preparation, screening, bidding, and contracting processes will 
enhance  the  direct  and  indirect  economic  impacts  of  individual  project  transactions.  Line 
ministries  and  other  agencies  are  paying  greater  attention  to  determining  the  expected 
economic and financial rates of return and assessing the benefits of proposed projects prior to 
their  approval.  This  helps  select  investments  with  higher  economic  returns  while  being 
financially  attractive  to  private  service  providers,  or  viable  to  public  providers.  Through  its 
secretariat, KKPPI reviews the financial and economic analyses for all proposed PPP projects. 
The IRSDP provides support to the KKPPI secretariat in this regard, and ensures that sound 
assessments are carried out and the economic benefits are highlighted. Overall progress in 
structural reforms and in removing infrastructure bottlenecks will improve the private sector 
enabling environment and medium- to long-term growth prospects, while significant near-term

33
investments in infrastructure construction leveraged by the IRSDP boost capital formation and 
generate related employment and business for the construction industry.   
 
105.  Resettlement, Indigenous People, and the Environment. Presidential regulations 
36/2005 and 65/2006 recognize traditional communal land ownership (Hak Ulayat) and usufruct 
rights. In line with the regulatory provisions, the rights of indigenous peoples will be upheld in 
the  case  of  any  land  acquisition  involving  them.  These  provisions  are  in  conformity  with 
requirements outlined in ADB's Policy on Indigenous Peoples (1998). Most of the reforms 
supported by the IRSDP help improve environmental outcomes through better sanitation, higher 
electricity prices to promote energy conservation, promotion of recycling, and sanitary landfills. 
Based on a desk review, the IRSDP measures are unlikely to have any adverse environmental 
impacts. Further, while the IRSDP facilitates the preparation and tendering of several model 
PPP projects, it does not provide any investment support to such projects. Nonetheless, the 
Government,  through  KKPPI,  will  ensure  that  all  social  and  environmental  safeguards  are 
complied with in line with the prevailing laws and regulations. Any projects to receive ADB 
financing must comply with all of ADB’s social and environmental safeguards requirements, as 
investment in this sector may lead to possible negative environmental impacts.  
 
B.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
106.  Government Commitment. The political commitment could possibly waver because of 
internal disagreements over policy directions, or because the entire Government may change 
after the elections in 2009. The majority of opinions within the current Government confirm the 
notion that the Government remains strongly committed to the reform program embodied in the 
IRSDP and the complementing IDPL program. The 2009 elections pose only a moderate risk of 
weakened  commitment  and  a  loss  of  the  reform  momentum,  as  even  with  a  change  of 
Government, the new leaders are expected to continue focusing on economic growth and 
poverty reduction to ensure a sound tenure in office and mitigate social and political unrest. 
However, should the new Government not be committed to maintaining the reform momentum, 
subprogram 3 could be delayed or cancelled.  
 
107.  Government Coordination. At times, the progress of infrastructure reforms has been 
impeded by poor coordination among government ministries and agencies, and competing and 
conflicting interests of various stakeholders. While full and effective coordination and reforms in 
certain sectors may take time to evolve and needs further consensus building, the essential 
steps taken thus far will have a demonstrational effect in supporting infrastructure development 
in a coordinated manner in the coming years.   
 
108.  Government Capacity. While the Government remains committed to reform objectives, 
the ability to translate that commitment into practical reform achievements is subject to available 
capacity within the different government ministries and agencies. In several areas, progress has 
been slower than was anticipated by the Government when the IRSDP was agreed upon. This 
has typically been the result of low capacity, compounded by weak coordination. Mitigation 
strategies  include  realistic  outputs  and  schedules  based  on  likely  reform  progress,  and 
continued provision of TA for capacity building. 
 
109.  Poor Governance and Corruption. With the high stakes involved in large infrastructure 
projects in several sectors, the IRSDP may face significant impediments in the form of weak 
governance, collusion, and corruption, or lack of judicial capacity to enforce good-governance 
measures.  In  particular,  despite  the  commendable  rigid  stance  taken  by  MOF,  risks  of 
misallocation of scarce public resources could still be encountered during the transition period, 
leading to government support for directly negotiated projects or projects that do not meet all 
relevant criteria for such support. However, during the last few years the Government has 
considerably strengthened its anticorruption efforts. Procurement reforms have been under way

34    
for some time, resulting in a competitive and transparent selection of bidders by the public 
sector. The PSP legal framework sets out clear rules for the selection of private sector sponsors 
for  PPP  projects.  KKPPI  is  tasked  with  ensuring  that  tendering  processes  are  fair  and 
transparent. The president of Indonesia has considerably enhanced the profile and activities of 
the Anti-Corruption Commission and other law enforcement agencies. These steps are already 
having a significant impact.    
 
110.   Economic Stability. Domestic macroeconomic volatility, adverse global events such as 
high oil and food prices, natural disasters, or the lack of sustained momentum on policy reforms 
could impede PSP. However, over the last few years, the Indonesian economy has been quite 
resilient to domestic and external shocks, and the Government’s macroeconomic policies have 
been sound. There is a risk of an adverse market reaction to growing expenditures on energy 
subsidies. Indonesia has considerable gross financing needs and the cost of meeting these will 
almost certainly go up if outlays on oil subsidies and budgetary financing needs continue to go 
up. In such an environment, a sharp deterioration in global economic conditions could make 
Indonesia particularly vulnerable to sudden shifts in investor sentiment, possibly triggering rapid 
capital outflows and raising the risks of broader financial sector disruption.  
 
111.  Social Tensions. Tariff reforms are sensitive in any environment, and Indonesia is no 
exception. As the country is gradually moving away from administered prices and tariffs for 
infrastructure products and services, social tensions are inevitable. However, the Government 
has so far been successful in reducing such tensions by the two-pronged approach of (i) 
comprehensively socializing any planned price and tariff increases, and (ii) using the savings 
from the reduction in inefficient subsidies for direct poverty reduction, employment generation, 
and rural infrastructure development.
